I also make the experien=
ce to think in terms of behaviors of the
class under test and the methods. =
For myself I think thats the best
way to test the special class behavior as=
 also method behavior in
one test class. But more over I use the following =
way...
If classes have similar behaviors, for example definied by
interface=
s or abstract classes I group my tests into similar
classes, for example *V=
iewTest, *ServiceTest. That saves many
time of coding tests for similar cla=
sses with the same expected
behavior. The very nice side-effect: test metho=
ds stay in the
right test classes.

Imagine you have a complex service with=
 dozens of methods and
each method is definied with up to 5 differently act=
ion paths.
So you may get up to 100 test methods in one class under test.
M=
y own solutions is to devide it into some test classes for
example an Accou=
ntingService that provides serveral methodes
for accounting and some other =
central accounting information
to test:

BaseAccountOperationServiceTest
	(=
tests the base account operations: add, sub, exceptions)
AdvancedAccountOpe=
rationServiceTest
	(tests the advanced account operations: dispo, change)
T=
empAccountServiceTest
	(tests the additonal behavior of temporary acccounts=
)
CustomerServiceAccountingServiceTest
	(tests the behavior of the Accounti=
ngService in conjunction
	of the customer service thats used by the Account=
ingService)

Back to your case I would write one test class CreateReportRep=
ortManagerTest
to test all behaviors of report creation. I assume that your=

ReportManager has some other behaviors not only creation. So you write
Exp=

rTest
